title: 1980 Rallye Automobile Monte-Carlo
bio: Walter Röhrl's precise and dominant win at Monte Carlo in a Fiat 131 Abarth marked the rise of one of rally’s greatest drivers.

title: 1980 Swedish Rally
bio: The only true snow rally on the WRC calendar, the 1980 Swedish Rally highlighted Scandinavian driving prowess, with Anders Kulläng taking victory.

title: 1980 Safari Rally
bio: The grueling African Safari Rally once again destroyed vehicles and exhausted drivers, with Björn Waldegård surviving to claim victory.

title: 1980 Rally de Portugal
bio: Fast, dusty stages and unpredictable conditions made Portugal one of the most thrilling events of the year, with Hannu Mikkola victorious.

title: 1980 Acropolis Rally
bio: Dust, rocks, and punishing Greek mountains tested endurance again at the Acropolis Rally, favoring the most durable cars.

title: 1980 1000 Lakes Rally
bio: Finland’s signature rally was a high-speed blur through forests and over famous jumps, with local drivers dominating.

title: 1980 Tour de Corse
bio: Twisting tarmac roads along the cliffs of Corsica demanded perfect precision; Jean Ragnotti’s victory became one of the most celebrated.

title: 1980 RAC Rally (UK)
bio: The muddy forests of Britain closed out the WRC season, with Ford’s Escorts performing strongly once again.

title: 1981 Rallye Automobile Monte-Carlo
bio: Jean Ragnotti stunned the rally world by winning Monte Carlo in a Renault 5 Turbo, defeating the dominant Fiat and Ford teams.

title: 1981 Swedish Rally
bio: Stig Blomqvist took victory on the snow of Sweden, reinforcing Scandinavian dominance on the white stages.

title: 1981 Safari Rally
bio: Sheer endurance was key again in Kenya, with Shekhar Mehta claiming another historic Safari Rally win.

title: 1981 Rally de Portugal
bio: Dust and massive crowds marked the 1981 Portugal Rally, with fierce battles between Fiat and Ford teams.

title: 1981 Acropolis Rally
bio: The Greek Acropolis Rally destroyed even the best machines with brutal rocky roads and brutal heat.

title: 1981 1000 Lakes Rally
bio: The fastest rally of the year saw local heroes once again dominate the high-speed, jump-filled Finnish stages.

title: 1981 Sanremo Rally
bio: Lancia returned strong on home soil, fighting Fiat and Opel on a mixture of gravel and tarmac in the Italian Riviera.

title: 1981 RAC Rally (UK)
bio: A dramatic season-ending RAC Rally in Britain saw Ari Vatanen crowned the 1981 World Rally Champion in a privateer Ford Escort.

title: 1982 Rallye Automobile Monte-Carlo
bio: The mighty Audi Quattro made history at Monte Carlo, with Hannu Mikkola winning the first ever WRC rally for a 4WD car.

title: 1982 Swedish Rally
bio: Stig Blomqvist dominated his home event in the Audi Quattro, showcasing the true advantage of all-wheel drive on snow and ice.

title: 1982 Safari Rally
bio: Shekhar Mehta continued his reign in Africa, winning the Safari for the fifth time in a Datsun 240RS.

title: 1982 Rally de Portugal
bio: Massive dust storms and enormous crowds lined the Portuguese stages as Audi Quattro claimed another dominant win.

title: 1982 Acropolis Rally
bio: Mechanical durability was the deciding factor once again on Greece’s brutal rocky stages; Opel took a crucial victory.

title: 1982 1000 Lakes Rally
bio: The Flying Finns reigned supreme again at Finland’s fastest rally, with Ari Vatanen leading a flat-out charge through the forests.

title: 1982 Rallye Sanremo (Italy)
bio: Mixed surfaces and home advantage let Lancia strike back at Sanremo, showing that Group B was going to become a real arms race.

title: 1982 RAC Rally (UK)
bio: Opel and Audi fought hard through the foggy British forests, with rally fans lining the cold muddy tracks in record numbers.

title: 1983 Rallye Automobile Monte-Carlo
bio: Walter Röhrl piloted the Lancia 037 to a heroic tarmac win against the Audi Quattro’s 4WD advantage, proving driver skill could still beat technology.

title: 1983 Swedish Rally
bio: Stig Blomqvist leveraged the Audi Quattro’s four-wheel drive traction to win on snow, further pushing Audi’s dominance on slippery surfaces.

title: 1983 Safari Rally
bio: Unforgiving African roads tested the new breed of rally monsters, but reliability still ruled the Safari, with Mitsubishi surprising many.

title: 1983 Rally de Portugal
bio: Dusty, rough stages favored the ruggedness of Lancia’s 037, keeping their championship hopes alive in the brutal Portuguese countryside.

title: 1983 Tour de Corse (France)
bio: Tarmac mastery was on full display as Lancia’s mid-engined 037 crushed the narrow, twisting mountain roads of Corsica.

title: 1983 Acropolis Rally (Greece)
bio: The Acropolis remained a brutal test of machinery and stamina; Audi struck back hard with a victory on the punishing Greek rocks.

title: 1983 1000 Lakes Rally (Finland)
bio: Flying Finns ruled their home rally again, soaring through the forests at incredible speeds, with Audi showing its rally pedigree.

title: 1983 RAC Rally (UK)
bio: Audi’s dominance sealed the manufacturers' title, but it was a hard-fought season finale through the slippery British forests.

title: 1984 Rallye Automobile Monte-Carlo
bio: Walter Röhrl showcased the raw power of the Audi Quattro A2, mastering the snow and tarmac of Monte Carlo yet again.

title: 1984 Swedish Rally
bio: Stig Blomqvist powered through Sweden’s frozen forests to claim another dominant snow rally victory for Audi.

title: 1984 Safari Rally
bio: Sheer toughness won the day again in Africa, as local knowledge and ruggedness overcame the increasingly fragile Group B monsters.

title: 1984 Rally de Portugal
bio: Audi’s dominance continued in the dusty Portuguese stages, although early signs of Peugeot's pace were appearing.

title: 1984 Tour de Corse (France)
bio: Corsica's endless corners and tight tarmac favored agility — the Peugeot 205 T16 hinted at a revolution to come.

title: 1984 Acropolis Rally (Greece)
bio: Audi’s rugged Quattros conquered the brutal Greek roads, but mechanical attrition remained the key enemy.

title: 1984 1000 Lakes Rally (Finland)
bio: High-speed gravel flying through Finnish forests suited the Audi and local heroes like Blomqvist, who claimed victory.

title: 1984 RAC Rally (UK)
bio: Blomqvist closed out the season with Audi's RAC win, sealing the drivers’ and manufacturers’ titles before Peugeot could fully rise.

title: 1985 Rallye Automobile Monte-Carlo
bio: Peugeot 205 T16 Evo 1s dominated Monte Carlo, with Ari Vatanen driving flat-out to secure an epic win against Audi.

title: 1985 Swedish Rally
bio: Stig Blomqvist returned strong on home snow, fending off Peugeot’s charge with Audi’s revised Quattro S1.

title: 1985 Safari Rally
bio: African endurance once again proved key, as the larger, heavier 4WD cars struggled against mechanical carnage.

title: 1985 Rally de Portugal
bio: Massive crowds packed the Portuguese stages, where Peugeot’s T16s overwhelmed the competition on dusty, treacherous roads.

title: 1985 Tour de Corse (France)
bio: Corsica's tragic rally: rising speeds and lack of safety led to the death of Attilio Bettega, marking the beginning of Group B's growing controversies.

title: 1985 Acropolis Rally (Greece)
bio: Dust, rocks, and extreme mechanical punishment defined the Acropolis once again, where the toughest teams survived, but few thrived.

title: 1985 1000 Lakes Rally (Finland)
bio: The home of the Flying Finns witnessed Ari Vatanen’s high-speed mastery until a brutal crash ended his title hopes.

title: 1985 RAC Rally (UK)
bio: Torrential rains and endless mud turned the RAC Rally into a war of attrition, with Timo Salonen securing the drivers’ championship for Peugeot.

title: 1986 Rallye Automobile Monte-Carlo
bio: Henri Toivonen piloted the Lancia Delta S4 to a dominant win, showing the terrifying speed of the new Group B cars on ice and tarmac.

title: 1986 Swedish Rally
bio: Swedish specialists excelled once again in the snow, but concerns about Group B car safety were beginning to surface even here.

title: 1986 Rally de Portugal
bio: Crowd control disasters marred Portugal, where reckless spectator behavior led to a catastrophic accident, killing three fans.

title: 1986 Safari Rally (Kenya)
bio: Africa's brutal stages once again demanded reliability over pure speed, offering a rare respite from Group B’s extreme dangers.

title: 1986 Tour de Corse (France)
bio: Henri Toivonen and co-driver Sergio Cresto were tragically killed when their Lancia Delta S4 plunged off a Corsican cliff, immediately sealing Group B’s fate.

title: 1986 Acropolis Rally (Greece)
bio: Despite growing safety concerns, the Acropolis Rally punished drivers with relentless rocky terrain and brutal mechanical attrition.

title: 1986 1000 Lakes Rally (Finland)
bio: Flying Finns like Juha Kankkunen and Timo Salonen thrilled the crowds at breathtaking speeds through the forest jumps of Finland.

title: 1986 RAC Rally (UK)
bio: The final rally of the Group B era was soaked in rain and reflection; Audi, Peugeot, and Lancia bowed out of the most dangerous rally era in history.

title: 1987 Rallye Automobile Monte-Carlo
bio: The new Group A Lancia Delta HF 4WD stunned the rally world by winning Monte Carlo immediately after Group B's ban, proving 4WD was still king.

title: 1987 Swedish Rally
bio: Lancia continued its momentum, with the Delta HF 4WD conquering snowy Swedish roads in its second event ever.

title: 1987 Safari Rally (Kenya)
bio: Long distances, extreme dust, and wild terrain defined Safari as always, but now Group A machines proved they could survive it too.

title: 1987 Rally de Portugal
bio: Crowd sizes remained massive despite post-Group B changes, and Lancia maintained dominance on Portugal's treacherous gravel.

title: 1987 Tour de Corse (France)
bio: Tarmac precision mattered again in Corsica, where the lighter Group A cars showed spectacular handling compared to their monstrous predecessors.

title: 1987 Acropolis Rally (Greece)
bio: The rough Greek stages remained brutal as ever, favoring cars like the Lancia Delta and Toyota Celica that could take the punishment.

title: 1987 1000 Lakes Rally (Finland)
bio: Flying Finns adapted quickly to Group A, keeping the speeds breathtaking as Juha Kankkunen led the way through high-speed forests.

title: 1987 RAC Rally (UK)
bio: Fog, mud, and rain made the British forests as treacherous as ever, with Lancia closing the season by sealing both championships.

title: 1988 Rallye Automobile Monte-Carlo
bio: Miki Biasion opened Lancia’s domination in Monte Carlo with a smooth and commanding drive in the new Delta Integrale.

title: 1988 Swedish Rally
bio: Sweden's frozen stages saw local driver Kenneth Eriksson shine, but Lancia still managed a strong finish.

title: 1988 Safari Rally (Kenya)
bio: The punishing African terrain once again favored durability, and Toyota began to show serious strength with their Celica GT-Four.

title: 1988 Rally de Portugal
bio: Lancia stayed dominant on Portugal's rough stages, with Miki Biasion controlling the rally from start to finish.

title: 1988 Tour de Corse (France)
bio: Corsica's endless twists and mountain roads demanded tarmac mastery, and Lancia once again crushed the opposition.

title: 1988 Acropolis Rally (Greece)
bio: Greek rocks and dust destroyed cars as usual, but Lancia’s Integrales proved tough enough to survive and win.

title: 1988 1000 Lakes Rally (Finland)
bio: Local heroes set blistering speeds through the Finnish forests, but Lancia managed to keep their championship momentum rolling.

title: 1988 RAC Rally (UK)
bio: Mud, fog, and rain returned to Britain, but Lancia sealed a crushing season with another RAC victory.

title: 1989 Rallye Automobile Monte-Carlo
bio: Miki Biasion started the season strong by winning Monte Carlo again, securing Lancia’s grip on the championship early.

title: 1989 Swedish Rally
bio: Mikael Ericsson gave Lancia another win on snow and ice, fending off a strong Scandinavian challenge.

title: 1989 Safari Rally (Kenya)
bio: Toyota’s Celica GT-Four proved its toughness by conquering the brutal Safari, signaling that Lancia had serious competition now.

title: 1989 Rally de Portugal
bio: Dusty Portuguese stages played perfectly to Lancia’s strengths, with Biasion maintaining his championship momentum.

title: 1989 Tour de Corse (France)
bio: Precision was key in Corsica’s tight turns, and Lancia again dominated the French tarmac labyrinth.

title: 1989 Acropolis Rally (Greece)
bio: Greek rocks destroyed suspensions and tires, but the Lancia Integrale’s toughness carried it through to another victory.

title: 1989 1000 Lakes Rally (Finland)
bio: The Finns flew once again at 1000 Lakes, but Toyota showed its growing speed by pushing Lancia to the edge.

title: 1989 RAC Rally (UK)
bio: Fog, rain, and slippery British forests closed out the season, with Toyota and Carlos Sainz announcing themselves as serious threats for the 1990s.
